qas.question: What is the consequence of the number and geographic location ascribed to a race highly dependent on?

answers.text: the importance attributed to, and quantity of, the traits considered.

qas.question: What partially accounts for the appearance of light skin in humans?
What do East Asians have to thank for their relatively light skin?
Traits and gene frequencies do not always correspond to what type of location?

context: Patterns such as those seen in human physical and genetic variation as described above, have led to the consequence that the number and geographic location of any described races is highly dependent on <a0_0>the importance attributed to, and quantity of, the traits considered.<a0_0/> Scientists discovered a <a1_0>skin-lighting<a1_0/> <a2_0>mutation<a2_0/> that partially accounts for the appearance of Light skin in humans (people who migrated out of Africa northward into what is now Europe) which they estimate occurred 20,000 to 50,000 years ago. The East Asians owe their relatively light skin to <a3_0>different mutations<a3_0/>. On the other hand, the greater the number of traits (or alleles) considered, the more subdivisions of humanity are detected, since traits and gene frequencies do not always correspond to the same <a4_0>geographical<a4_0/> location. Or as Ossorio & Duster (2005) put it:
